awd_titl_txt: The use of remote sensing in landscape and social reconstruction
awd_abstract_narration:
An interdisciplinary and international team of researchers, led by the University of Florida, will conduct research on the history of land use and landscape resilience under different land use regimes and settlement patterns in the Maya lowlands of southern Mexico. Specifically focused on terraced landscapes, the scientists will investigate how key cultural (e.g., population density), ecological (e.g., soil and topography), and climatological (e.g., annual precipitation) factors influence changing patterns of agrarian land use. Previous research has documented discrete systems of terracing in parts of the lowlands, importantly demonstrating that these landscapes were sometimes intensively curated and cultivated. Combining soil science, paleoethnobotany, remote sensing, and archaeology with existing "big environmental data" (LiDAR surveys of Above Ground Carbon Storage), the research will investigate these agrarian systems across ecologies and settlement patterns, critically evaluating the resilience of these systems across the Maya lowlands. Are terraces constructed only in response to population pressure? Why are terraces built in particular regions? Why do they endure in certain ecological settings and not in others? Does terracing in the lowlands increase local landscape resilience? Do communities maintain terrace systems once they are built? Throughout the world, questions of landscape resilience, especially related to smallholder agriculture are vitally important to address, so that we can better design, plan, organize and maintain systems that are resilient to cultural and ecological change. This project fosters international collaborations and provides research opportunities for enhancing student engagement.

The project will investigate the long-term landscape impacts of increasing agricultural intensity in the Maya lowlands of southern Mexico. It will inventory and analyze remote sensing (LiDAR) transects extending from the states of Chiapas north to Yucatan and Quintana Roo. Originally collected for environmental purposes as part of the REDD+ carbon inventory of southern Mexico, these surveys offer a uniquely expansive survey of human modified landscapes and landscape resilience. Specifically, it will explore how the form and spatial distribution of Pre-Columbian intensive agricultural modifications of the landscape are influenced by settlement density. The research will also study the influence of local environmental variability on the form and distribution of terracing. To address these questions, the team will process, analyze, inventory, and annotate existing LiDAR transects from across the Maya lowlands. This information will be combined with regional environmental data, excavation, soil profiles, and new high precision UAV LiDAR field surveys in order to evaluate land use intensity and land use change. The project will develop new methods and metrics for studying agrarian systems and agrarian change through time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project investigated the complex relationships among communities, society, and landscape across the southern Maya lowlands in Mexico. Relying on remote sensing and archaeological field research, we documented thousands of Ancient Maya households, communities, and associated land use from the southern state of Chiapas, Mexico to the northern coast of the Yucatan. Our work recovered important information about the social organization of past Maya communities, especially from a deep time perspective. In a number of publications, we documented the important role of green space and agrarian systems as they related to Ancient Maya cities and settlements. Additionally, we tested and advanced important experimental scientific methods. Our research is transformative in three key areas: 1) we advanced our scientific understanding of the past using non-invasive remote sensing and in particular big environmental data; 2) we developed, tested, and applied new scientific methods to study the past, including the first successful application of drone LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) in the Maya lowlands and the development of new geospatial tools for archaeology, for example, google earth engine; and, 3) we developed important comparative information about deep time land use and how it compares to modern shifts in populations, communities, and land use.

First, we successfully reanalyzed and repurposed environmental ‘big data’ and used this information to reconstruct the form and distribution of Maya communities. We used this information to better understand the relationship between past communities and regional ecological systems, such as water availability, precipitation, and soil resources. Importantly, we also examined how this information could be used to understand inequality across the Maya lowlands, not specific to one ancient city or archaeological site. We found that while there are unexpected high population densities across the lowlands as also documented by other scientists, there was also an abundance of agricultural land and natural areas ensuring long-term community resilience.

Second, we deployed new scientific technologies and methods to study and interpret the past. This includes the use, application, and systematic study of drone-based LiDAR. We compared these data with airborne and spaceborne remote sensing. We tested multiple cameras and continue to refine this technology. Importantly, we used these samples to evaluate methods for integrating a variety of remote sensing data, including open source data available through Google Earth Engine. Relying on machine learning, we developed techniques for studying the relationship between past communities and key environmental systems.

Third, our project offers scientific information from the past that compares to important questions about modern city design and land use decision making. This information is both specific to questions about the balance between the built environment and natural systems and offers a valuable historical narrative about how communities are shaped and respond to environmental change. Simply, the Ancient Maya landscape offers critical stories of how cities and communities can respond to regional environmental systems, strengthening resilience and sustainability.

Our planet has been shaped and influenced directly and indirectly by thousands of years of human decision making. It offers an indelible archive of our lives, our families, and our communities. Our research offers new perspectives and methods to scientifically study the past in order to better plan and design our future.
